result.execSummary:
The defendant Richard Lee Newcomb was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.descr: Notice of court ordered financial obligations

records.addlTxt: State informs the Court defendant will plead to 16CM18 and has 2 uncharged worthless checks that will pay restitution today and the DA will not charge.  Court advises defendant of charge/max. penalties. Defendant pleads no contest.  Plea Colloquy. Court finds defendant's waiver of his constitutional rights & plea done knowingly & voluntarily, accepts plea and finds defendant guilty. Subject to defendant paying restitution to DA today, Court withholds sentence and places defendant on 12 mos. probation with conditions:  comply with any assessment or couseling required by P&P; pay costs $443.00; note no charges will be filed by the DA arising from the worthless checks.
Defendant Richard Lee Newcomb in court with attorney Gary E. Smith.  Jon D. Seifert appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Parties trying to resolve.  Off the record.
Adjourned initial appearance on September 6, 2016 at 02:30 pm.

Attorney Gary E. Smith in court.  Defendant f/t/a.  Jon D. Seifert appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant in custody in another county.  Adjourn to 9/6/16.  Adjourned initial appearance scheduled for September 6, 2016 at 02:30 pm.

Court advised defendant of charge/max. penalties and rights.  No request for bond by State, defendant in custody in Dunn County & to remain there until Aug. 24, 2016.
